No, 2.5 MPa is roughly the stress exerted by a ring finger. It's about the 
same flexural stress as snapping a (big) matchstick. Keep in mind your 
finger is has quite a large surface area and it's all about the surface 
area when it comes to stress. This is of course, assuming you can produce 
~100N from your ring finger alone which is quite possible. I suppose for 
some, the middle, index finger or even your palm would be a more 
appropriate example.

For the test they're doing, I assume they have to have a large area low 
stress point anyways else it'll start indenting the phone before it can 
simulate the flexural bending.

+Bmo
I would say that 2.5 MPa is a lot more than finger ring pressure.

+EgAnimatiOn  Mm three point bend isn't exactly a single point pressure 
btw. It is rather low though even if we look at their point pressure test. 
25 kgf is ~ 250N, and if we assume their point load is about .01 m^2 it's 
still only 2.5 MPa of stress at the single point, which is pretty weak. 
It's about the same as someone pushing down using their ring finger. To be 
honest, their lab seems pretty incompetent to not set baselines (i.e a 
control) to compare with. If they had established the flexural strength of 
their older phones and then use it as the baseline for their new phoens and 
identify the exact point where it changes from elastic to plastic, they 
probably would have found that the 6 plus was severely under performing. 
Instead, they chose to go with the let's establish an arbitrary 
underestimated minimum force we find acceptable and cyclic load it to make 
sure it won't fail from fatigue. Imo, the OP is correct to use something 
more realistic e.g. > 60 kgf just to be sure and probably better off using 
4 point bend.

Lastly, it's pretty pointless for apple to say "see look we do test our 
device" because at the end of the day, your phones are still bending under 
relatively low forces so all you're saying is we have all these test done 
but our employees are incompetent.
